body.head: George A. Wedge (born Danbury, CT, Jan 15, 1890; died Barbados, Oct 31, 1964)

div.p: George A. Wedge (born Danbury, CT, Jan 15, 1890; died Barbados, Oct 31, 1964), American organist and music teacher.

Wedge studied organ, piano, and composition at the Institute of Musical Art in New York, and subsequently taught at New York University (1920-27), the Curtis Institute of Music, Philadelphia (1924-26), then became the Dean of the Institute of Musical Art, also that of the Juilliard School of Music (1938-46). He wrote books on ear-training, sight-singing, keyboard harmony, and rhythm.

As early as 1925, Gerald F. Warburg reported that Wedge was "lecturing on the Urline at the Damrosch Conservatory [i.e. Institute of Musical Art]" (OJ 3/8, p. 2876). In a 1932 interview, Irvin Kolodin, who studied at the Institute while Wedge was teaching there, described him as "a pioneer in [Schenker's] work in America." Hans Weisse speaks of Wedge as: "the chief director of the Institute of Musical Art, who has been teaching according to your books for a long, long time, and is dying to meet me and learn more from me." (OJ 15/16, [82], October 15, 1931). Wedge is said to have produced a graph of the "Liebestod" from Wagner's Tristan und Isolde (Berry).
There is no known correspondence between Wedge and Schenker.
Baker's1971 David Carson Berry, "Hans Weisse and the Dawn of American Schenkerism," Journal of Musicology xx/1 (Winter 2003), p. 151.
